Name: Vatican Museums
Last 5 Reviews:
[]Author: Claudia Andrea C;
Rating: 5
When: 9 months ago
A must! I would highly recommend to assign half a day to the museums, in order to see everything inside. It is really big and it could take a while to finish it. Take comfy shoes because you will walk a lot. Also don't forget your water.

Author: James Blassingame;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
If you find yourself in Rome, do what the Romans do.........check out The Vatican!!! The earlier in the day that you can get there the better off you will be. This place gets PACKED!!! Not really an issue right now, but when school is in session the school groups swamp the place, and that's not even mentioning regular tourist. The setting is immaculate, absolutely beautiful. One thing that I noticed, there was a legit military/law enforcement presence at the Vatican. If someone is going there with the intention of breaking bad, I pray for their soul. The armed guards aren't playing, and looked legit as any military operation I can think of. The Sistine Chapel is a sight to behold, worth the churning herd of people to see it in person. Don't pull your cameras out, they don't take too kindly to that either. This isn't from personal experience, but I didn't see some people who encountered issues.

Author: Mrs Mrs;
Rating: 5

A fantastic museum that is like a time capsule. There are displays that go back as far as Constantine, all the way up to the present day. We were lucky enough to have come on an evening tour and the museum was not crowded. Our tour guide was able to give fantastic insight into the pieces of art and relics on display. The artwork on the ceiling is amazing, it looks like 3D plaster but it's not it's actually all hand painted!

Author: Tony Popa;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
The Museo di Roma is a museum in Rome, Italy, part of the network of Roman civic museums. The museum was founded in the Fascist era with the aim of documenting the local history and traditions of the "old Rome" that was rapidly disappearing, but following many donations and acquisitions of works of art is now principally an art museum. The collections initially included 120 water-colours by the nineteenth-century painter Ettore Roesler Franz of Roma sparita, "vanished Rome", later moved to the Museo di Roma in Trastevere.

Author: Dave Ruijer;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
Fun and interactive museum about the great ideas and creations from Leonardo Da Vinci. We went late afternoon without a line stopping us to enter the museum quickly. By entrance you get a map of the museum with pictures of the objects on it. With a little scanner, headphone included, you can tab on the picture what is relevant at the moment you stand in front of an object. You will here a voice in your selected language explaining the background of the piece. Several mechanical creations can be tried. By doing this you get close in the genius mind of Leonardo Da Vinci and realize he went far in front of his era. Also for kids this is a very educative museum wich stimulates the mind. After the tour in the museum you can buy fun souvenirs like T-shirts, books, etc.

Author: JUZER KAPADIA;
Rating: 5
When: 2 months ago
The wealthy Sienese banker Agostino Chigi commissioned this villa in 1508 for his lavish banquets and for sojourns with the courtesan Imperia, who allegedly inspired one of the Three Graces painted by Raphael in the Loggia of Cupid and Psyche. Designed by the Sienese architect Baldassare Peruzzi, the harmonious Farnesina, with a central block and projecting wings, is one of the first true Renaissance villas. Peruzzi decorated some of the interiors himself, such as the Sala della Prospettiva upstairs, in which illusionistic frescoes create the impression of looking out over Rome through a marble colonnade. The painted vault of the Sala di Galatea shows the position of the stars at the time of Chigi’s birth. After his death, the banking business collapsed, and in 1577 the villa was sold to the Farnese family.

Last 5 Reviews:
[]Author: EWTN Vatican;
Rating: 5
When: 6 months ago
The Church of the Sacred Heart of Suffrage is an incredible, mysterious, but also very particular Church. It is the only church in Rome built in the neo-gothic style, but what makes it really special is a small room located next to the sacristy. It is a small museum of the Holy Souls of Purgatory.

Author: Jaroslav Madacki;
Rating: 4
When: 9 months ago
In the Catholic faith, souls pass through Purgatory on their way to heaven. You pay for your sins in Purgatory and the soul makes its way through faster if more of the living say prayers to speed them along. In earlier centuries, people handed out ‘soul cakes’ to the poor at Halloween, in exchange for the poor saying prayers for their relatives. But this truly strange museum displays objects apparently marked by burning hands belonging to the souls of Purgatory. According to legend, a fire in the original church inspired a French missionary to build the museum. He discovered the scorched image of a face which he assumed was a trapped soul.

Name: Museo Storico - Padiglione delle Carrozze
Last 5 Reviews:
[]Author: Jaydeep Ravani;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
The museum consists of two large sections: - the Historical Museum proper, which is located in the Lateran Palace; it preserves an iconographic series of the Popes from the sixteenth century to today; the most significant finds from the papal military corps, the Chapel and the Papal Family, and the various papal ceremonials no longer in use; - the Carriage Pavilion, located in the Vatican Museums, where the testimonies concerning papal mobility (the popemobiles) are preserved, that is saddles, sedan chairs, carriages, cars, all accompanied by paintings and photographs. The entrance ticket to the Vatican Museums entitles you to visit the Vatican Museums and Sistine Chapel for the day of issue only and allows you to visit, within the following 5 days (including the day of issue), the Historical Museum and the Noble Apartment of the Lateran Apostolic Palace in Piazza S. Giovanni in Laterano.

First book your tickets at home in the internet for a wednesday morning as early as possible. On wednesday the pope greets all the tourists at St. Peter's and the Vatican museums are much quieter. After entering the museum get as fast as possible to the rooms of Raphael and the Sistine Chapel of Michelangelo and stay as long as possible. Then return to the other masterpieces...

Name: Gregorian Egyptian Museum
Last 5 Reviews:
[]Author: Lina S. Low;
Rating: 5
When: 5 months ago
Its nine rooms exhibit some fine examples of Egyptian art from the third millennium to the sixth century BC. Highlights include basalt and wooden sarcophagi, sculptures of gods and pharaohs, bronzes, mummified heads, stelae with hieroglyphic inscriptions, statues of gods and animals, and papyri. It's quite eerie when I step into this room. I just took some photos and had a glance then i left the room quickly.

Author: Anu Haden;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
Quite possibly some of the oldest pieces in all of the Vatican museum. It has a large collection including mummies (one exposed so you can see its face and feet), sarcophaguses, statues, stone tablets, etc. Still fairly crowded with people, not as empty as the Etruscan wing of the museum. Even if you're short on time, I'd consider this gallery a must-see on your itinerary.

Name: Accademia dei Lincei
Last 5 Reviews:
[]Author: Carlo Carlevale;
Rating: 4
When: a month ago
It is one of the oldest scientific institutions in Europe. It was founded in Rome in 1603 by Federico Cesi, Francesco Stelluti, Anastasio De Filiis and Johannes van Heeck, in order to establish a meeting place for the development of the sciences. Its name refers to the sharpness that must have the sight of those who dedicate themselves to the sciences, to the future and to human progress, a property that characterizes the lynx, in relation to sight. The Accademia dei Lincei has undergone many changes over time. After a first period of great prestige, due to the work of Cesi and the other founders and to the presence of partners such as Galileo Galilei and Giovanni Battista Della Porta, after Cesi's death in 1630, the Academy reduced its activities to almost to disappear. Only in 1847 there was a real resumption of its activities by Pope Pius IX who re-founded it in the Pontifical Academy of the Nuovi Lincei, which still exists today. Subsequently from 1936 with the name of Pontifical Academy of Sciences. Since 1986 the Accademia dei Lincei has been governed by a Statute which provides for it to be composed of 540 academics, divided according to three qualifications. Therefore 180 are the "national" ordinary members, 180 the "foreign" ordinary members and 180 are the "corresponding" members. All members are then divided into two classes: the first is that of Physical Sciences, while the second is that of Moral Sciences. Since 2001 the Physical Sciences Class is divided into 5 categories, while the Moral Sciences Class is divided into 7 categories. The academy is located in the Villa Farnesina, in Rome; it was built between 1506 and 1512 by the young Peruzzi for the very wealthy Sienese banker Agostino Chigi, a great patron and prominent figure in early 16th century Rome, who had amassed a large fortune from the proceeds of the sale of the Tolfa alum and who enjoyed the protection of Pope Julius II first, and then Leo X. The Farnesina, which at the time was simply called Villa Chigi, was the first suburban noble villa in Rome and had a great prominence from the beginning, soon being cited and imitated. The architectural interventions, although they could be considered completed in 1512, continued for other works until 1520. With the death of Chigi, in 1520, the villa declined and was depleted of furnishings and works of art. In 1580 it was purchased by Cardinal Alessandro Farnese and thus had its current name. An unrealized project dates back to this period to connect Palazzo Farnese with the Farnesina with a covered passage. In 1714 it became the property of the Bourbons of Naples and in 1864 the ambassador Bermudez de Castro settled there, who, two years later, promoted a series of heavy restorations. In 1884 the opening of the Lungotevere involved the destruction of a part of the gardens and of the loggia on the river, which perhaps had been designed by Raphael. As already mentioned, it has belonged to the Italian State since 1927, which had it restored in 1929 -1942 to be assigned to the Academy of Italy and on several occasions in 1969-1983. Today it is used by the Accademia dei Lincei as a representative office and houses, on the first floor, the national print cabinet.
